word.entryDescription: easy to guess what will happen
word.entryExample: The ending was the most predictable of all his films.

word.entryDescription: a statement about what you think is going to happen; or making such a statement

word.entryDescription: to like or choose one thing rather than something else

word.entryDescription: having a baby developing inside the body

word.entryDescription: to heat an oven to a necessary temperature before you put food in it to cook

word.entryDescription: connected with the time in history before anything was written down
word.entryExample: Humans learned to cook with fire in prehistoric times.

word.entryDescription: to get something ready for the future

word.entryDescription: a piece of paper on which a doctor writes down the medicine or treatment needed

word.entryDescription: something you give to somebody, often on a special occasion such as a birthday
word.entryExample: Sally's got lots of birthday presents.

word.entryDescription: (of food) to prevent something from decaying by treating it in a particular way

word.entryDescription: to push a button, switch, key, etc on a machine, device, etc
word.entryExample: If they saw a happy face, they had to press the ‘yes’ key.

word.entryDescription: the force produced by something as it pushes on something else

word.entryDescription: admired and respected because of being important and one of the best
word.entryExample: This is one one of the most prestigious universities in our country.

word.entryDescription: good-looking, especially a girl or young woman
word.entryExample: This dress is very pretty.

word.entryDescription: to stop something from happening

word.entryDescription: something that can be stopped from happening

word.entryDescription: an animal that is hunted by another animal for food

word.entryDescription: the amount of money for which something is sold

word.entryDescription: the son of a king, queen or prince

word.entryDescription: an idea or a theory that something is based on

word.entryDescription: a copy of a painting that is produced by taking a photograph of it and printing it onto paper

word.entryDescription: to print a file on paper
word.entryExample: I couldn't print out my report as there was no paper left.

word.entryDescription: suitable to be printed

word.entryDescription: produced on paper, using a machine which puts ink onto the surface

word.entryDescription: a device which is connected to a computer and can make a printed record of computer information

word.entryDescription: the cable that carries data between a computer and a printer

word.entryDescription: a place where criminals are kept

word.entryDescription: in a pure or natural undamaged state

word.entryDescription: the state of being free from the presence or attention of other people

word.entryDescription: belonging to or for use by one person or group, not for everyone

word.entryDescription: something nice which is given to somebody who has been successful

word.entryDescription: a way of doing something, especially the usual or correct way

word.entryDescription: (of food) with substances added to it before it is sold, in order to preserve it, improve its colour etc

word.entryDescription: making food, materials, or goods ready to be used or sold, for example by preserving or improving them in some way

word.entryDescription: a part of a computer that controls all the other parts of the system

word.entryDescription: to make, write etc something to be bought, used, or enjoyed by people

word.entryDescription: a person, company or a country that grows or makes food, or makes other goods

word.entryDescription: something you watch on television or listen to on the radio

word.entryDescription: a planned piece of work with a particular aim

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'promise' – to say that something will definitely be done or happen

word.entryDescription: to help sell a product, service, etc. or make it more popular by advertising it or offering it at a special price

word.entryDescription: to make the sound of a letter, word etc, especially in the correct way

word.entryDescription: how individual sounds, and words, phrases and sentences are said

word.entryDescription: land, a building, an office, an apartment, etc which belongs to a person or an organisation

word.entryDescription: the most important character in a play, film, or story

word.entryDescription: to keep something or someone safe from harm, damage, loss, etc

word.entryDescription: the state of protecting something

word.entryDescription: a substance found in meat, eggs, dairy products, nuts, etc which helps the body to grow and stay strong

word.entryDescription: to express your disapproval of or opposition to something

word.entryDescription: the first version of a new product

word.entryDescription: thinking that you are more important, skilful etc than you really are

word.entryDescription: feeling pleased about yourself and your achievements or about someone or something you are involved with or related to

word.entryDescription: to give evidence to show that something is true

word.entryDescription: to give something to somebody or make it available for them to use

word.entryDescription: the study of the mind and behaviour

word.entryDescription: the stage during which children's bodies change into adult ones

word.entryDescription: where other people can see you

word.entryDescription: (usually plural) a service, such as transport or health care, that a government provides

word.entryDescription: methods of travelling such as trains, buses, trams, etc which are available for everybody to use

word.entryDescription: a person or company that deals with producing books, magazines, etc

word.entryDescription: a small pool of water on the ground, which often appears during rain

word.entryDescription: to injure a muscle by stretching it too much during physical activity

word.entryDescription: the soft part of a fruit – not the seeds

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'punctuate' – to interrupt something at intervals

word.entryDescription: to make somebody suffer because they have broken the law or done something wrong

word.entryDescription: a person who likes punk music (a type of loud and aggressive rock music popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s) and dresses like a punk musician

word.entryDescription: a child student

word.entryDescription: a young dog

word.entryDescription: something that is purple is the colour between red and blue

word.entryDescription: a small bag most often used by a woman to keep her money

word.entryDescription: to move something away from you or to another position usually with your hands

word.entryDescription: to move something into a particular position

word.entryDescription: to decide that something should happen later than previously arranged

word.entryDescription: to cover a part of your body with a piece of clothing

word.entryDescription: to become heavier or fatter

word.entryDescription: to try to force or to persuade somebody to do something

word.entryDescription: to connect somebody who is making a telephone call to somebody else

word.entryDescription: to prepare something by collecting pieces of information, ideas etc

word.entryDescription: to raise something to a higher position

word.entryDescription: small pieces of wood in different shapes that you join together to make a picture

word.entryDescription: clothes you wear in bed when you sleep

word.entryDescription: something you gain as a result of passing an examination or successfully completing a course

word.entryDescription: 15 minutes (to/past a time)

word.entryDescription: a woman who rules a country or a king's wife

word.entryDescription: something that someone asks you when they want information

word.entryDescription: a line of people or vehicles waiting for something

Sam is a quick runner.

word.entryDescription: in a fast way

word.entryDescription: making little or no sound

word.entryDescription: in a way which does not make a lot of sound

word.entryDescription: rather close, relatively close

word.entryDescription: a small furry animal with long ears and a short bushy tail, often kept for food or as a pet

word.entryDescription: a competition in which you try to finish faster than the others

word.entryDescription: the tracks that a train runs on, or the whole train system

word.entryDescription: drops of water that fall from clouds

word.entryDescription: to improve the quality or standard of something

word.entryDescription: very uncommon or unusual

word.entryDescription: fairly; quite

word.entryDescription: to get to or touch a place or point

word.entryDescription: to look at words or symbols in a book and understand what they mean

word.entryDescription: true in your mind or in the world and not false

word.entryDescription: something that is red is the colour of blood (=the liquid inside your body)

word.entryDescription: to make something smaller

word.entryDescription: a decrease in size, price, etc

word.entryDescription: a happy feeling caused by something unpleasant ending or not happening

word.entryDescription: to continue to be in the same state or place; e.g. upright or stable

word.entryDescription: to keep or bring back information, an image, a feeling, etc in your mind

word.entryDescription: to take something away from a place

word.entryDescription: energy that is replaced naturally, by natural ecological cycles

word.entryDescription: the money that you pay to rent something, particularly the regular payment for the use of someone's flat, building, land, etc

word.entryDescription: to pay to use something that belongs to someone else

word.entryDescription: to replace something that has been used

word.entryDescription: something that is said, written, or done as a way of replying

word.entryDescription: to say or write something in reaction to something somebody else has said or written

word.entryDescription: a person who reports news for a newspaper, on television, etc

word.entryDescription: when you ask for something politely or formally

word.entryDescription: to change the time at which something has been arranged

word.entryDescription: to save someone from a dangerous situation

word.entryDescription: detailed study of a particular subject in order to find out more about it or to test ideas

word.entryDescription: somebody who does research

word.entryDescription: to look like or be similar to somebody or something else

word.entryDescription: the place you come to for activity holidays

word.entryDescription: think about other people's feelings, wishes or rights

word.entryDescription: a place where you can go to have a meal

word.entryDescription: able to be used again for different data

word.entryDescription: (for words, lines of poetry, etc) to end with similar sounds

word.entryDescription: a repeated pattern of sounds, music, etc

word.entryDescription: a small piece of jewellery worn on the finger

word.entryDescription: to make a sound, characteristic of some metals when struck

word.entryExample: I can't work out how to use this sewing machine – can you help me?

word.entryDescription: to work hard, in a determined way, without stopping
word.entryExample: Our dedicated team at the High Rocks rare bird sanctuary work tirelessly to ensure that these bird populations are protected.

word.entryDescription: the Earth and all the people, places, and things on it
word.entryExample: Is the elephant the biggest animal in the world?

word.entryDescription: everywhere in the world
word.entryExample: The bicycle industry in India exports bicycles and bicycle parts worldwide.

word.entryDescription: unhappy because you keep thinking about something unpleasant
word.entryExample: Going to the dentist makes William feel worried.

word.entryDescription: more unpleasant than something else, the comparative of 'bad'
word.entryExample: I think wind is worse than rain.

word.entryDescription: most unpleasant of all other things, the superlative of 'bad'
word.entryExample: Sport is my worst subject.

word.entryDescription: having value
word.entryExample: Although learning another language isn't easy, it is well worth all the dedication.

word.entryDescription: useful or important and therefore worth spending effort, time, money, etc on
word.entryExample: She thinks working as a doctor would be very satisfying and worthwhile.

word.entryDescription: a type of injury where the skin is open, or from which blood flows
word.entryExample: The wound was so deep that I was afraid that I'd have to go to hospital.

word.entryDescription: injured by a weapon
word.entryExample: The wounded soldier asked me to send a letter to his family.

word.entryDescription: You say Wow! to show you are surprised or very happy
word.entryExample: Wow! This is really the most beautiful room in this flat.

word.entryDescription: (of skin/cloth) with small lines and folds
word.entryExample: She turned round and I saw her wrinkled face with a gentle smile and blue eyes.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body where your hand joins your arm
word.entryExample: He's sprained his wrist playing football.

word.entryDescription: to put language into a form that can be read, such as by pen on paper, by keyboard onto a computer screen, etc
word.entryExample: I'm writing a letter to my friend.

word.entryDescription: to write something again
word.entryExample: You have to write out your work right from the beginning.

word.entryDescription: to write something in a full and complete form, often using notes that you made earlier
word.entryExample: Sandra had to write up her English essay on her laptop.

word.entryDescription: not correct
word.entryExample: I'm sorry, that's the wrong answer.

word.entryDescription: a photograph taken or examination made using radiation that can pass through the body showing the things inside it
word.entryExample: I don't think it's broken but have an X-ray to be sure.

word.entryDescription: a comfortable boat with sails and often an engine, which is used for pleasure or sport
word.entryExample: I'd like to sail on a yacht around the islands.

word.entryDescription: a period of 12 months, particularly one that runs from January through to December
word.entryExample: The beginning of the year is January 1st.

word.entryDescription: something that is yellow, is the colour of a banana
word.entryExample: There are lots of yellow ducks on the farm.

word.entryDescription: on the day before today
word.entryExample: Where were you yesterday?

word.entryDescription: a thick slightly sour liquid made from milk
word.entryExample: He used to have yoghurt with the main meal.

word.entryDescription: not very old
word.entryExample: Jill is too young to go out by herself.

word.entryDescription: an expression used to end a formal letter
word.entryExample: Write 'Yours faithfully' if you wrote 'Dear Sir/Madam' at the start of the letter.

word.entryDescription: an expression used to end a formal letter
word.entryExample: Write 'Yours truly' in professional correspondence when you write to a client by his name, but sign the letter in the name of the firm.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to the person being spoken or written to, affected by an action when that person also performs the action
word.entryExample: What have you done to yourself?

word.entryDescription: a place where young people who are travelling, can stay very cheaply for a short time
word.entryExample: She works as a receptionist at the youth hostel.

word.entryDescription: young or seeming younger than you are
word.entryExample: He is 64 but his optimism has kept him youthful.

word.entryDescription: a kind of traditional tent, used e.g. in Mongolia
word.entryExample: I live in a yurt, which is a kind of round tent made on a strong wooden frame.

word.entryDescription: an African animal like a horse with black and white stripes
word.entryExample: Look, there's a zebra next to the trees.

word.entryDescription: a thin line of metal or plastic teeth which you use to fasten clothes
word.entryExample: I'm returning these trousers because the zip doesn't work!

word.entryDescription: (= postcode) a series of letters and numbers used as part of an address when you send something by post
word.entryExample: What is your zipcode, please?

word.entryDescription: a place where you can go to see animals
word.entryExample: Was the zoo very interesting?

word.entryDescription: a scientist who studies zoology (a study of animals and their behaviour)
word.entryExample: Rainforests give zoologists, botanists and biologists the opportunity to do research.
